title: Getting started
text: package designed simple use possible also allowing advanced customization. fact, since can upload tree metadata interactively, entirely valid create widget input: can also supply trees/metadata plot widget created. following types input data currently supported: Paths newick files Newick-formatted text (character vector single item) phylo objects ape package example, test data included package three formats: three commands produce plot: can also supply metadata tree supplying path TSV/CSV data.frame/tibble. table must “node_id” column values matching IDs treefile. example, data associated example tree: Similar tree input, paths parsed data accepted. Metadata can used color size tree elements, similar ggplot2 works. aesthetics parameter used specify columns correspond aesthetics. two commands produce plot: Check heat-tree javascript package documentation list valid aesthetics.

title: Getting started
text: Although widget primarily designed interactive use, initial settings can set programmatically. value options described heat-tree javascript package documentation can used optional parameters. example, layout can changed circular like :

title: Getting started
text: heat_tree widget capable managing multiple trees . initialize widget multiple trees, supply lists tree metadata inputs. metadata/aesthetics also supplied must list well corresponds list trees. example:
code: heat_tree(   tree = list(tree_1, tree_2),   metadata = list(metadata_1, metadata_2),   aesthetics = list(NULL, c(tipLabelColor = 'source') )

title: Authors and Citation
text: Zachary Foster. Author, maintainer. Niklaus Grunwald. Funder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Foster Z (2026). heattree: wrapper javascript 'heat-tree' package interactive phylogenetic tree visualization widgets. R package version 0.2.1, https://grunwaldlab.github.io/heattree/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {heattree: A wrapper for the javascript `heat-tree` package for interactive phylogenetic tree visualization widgets},   author = {Zachary Foster},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.2.1},   url = {https://grunwaldlab.github.io/heattree/}, }

what: A wrapper for the javascript `heat-tree` package for interactive phylogenetic tree visualization widgets
title: A wrapper for the javascript `heat-tree` package for interactive phylogenetic tree visualization widgets
text: package makes easy visualize, manipulate, export phylogenetic trees R using interactive viewer/editor. can insert tree viewer Rmd/Quarto documents make trees accessible online. want use web development outside R, consider javascript heat-tree package package builds upon.

title: A wrapper for the javascript `heat-tree` package for interactive phylogenetic tree visualization widgets
text: now, heattree available Github can installed devtools:

title: A wrapper for the javascript `heat-tree` package for interactive phylogenetic tree visualization widgets
text: package includes example data sets automatically loaded package (example_tree_1), can try minimal effort. installing packages, simply run lines get idea works:  See “Getting Started” page interactive examples
code: library(heattree) heat_tree(example_tree_1, metadata = example_metadata_1, aesthetics = c(tipLabelColor = 'source'), layout = 'circular')

title: A wrapper for the javascript `heat-tree` package for interactive phylogenetic tree visualization widgets
text: Contributions feedback welcome! Please visit GitHub repository report issues submit pull requests.

title: Shiny bindings for heat_tree — heat_tree-shiny
text: Output render functions using heat_tree within Shiny applications interactive Rmd documents.

title: Shiny bindings for heat_tree — heat_tree-shiny
code: heat_treeOutput(outputId, width = "100%", height = "400px")  renderheat_tree(expr, env = parent.frame(), quoted = FALSE)

title: Shiny bindings for heat_tree — heat_tree-shiny
text: outputId output variable read width, height Must valid CSS unit (like '100%', '400px', 'auto') number, coerced string 'px' appended. expr expression generates heat_tree env environment evaluate expr. quoted expr quoted expression (quote())? useful want save expression variable.
